scope: Lunar surface and orbital habitats including inflatable modules, rigid pressurized structures, and in-situ construction technologies at TRL 5+

items.model: LIFE (Large Integrated Flexible Environment) - Multiple Variants

trl.verification_notes: Confirmed TRL 6. Ground testing complete with 6 successful stress tests and 4 UBP tests. LIFE 10 achieved 255 psi burst pressure Oct 2024, completing certification requirements. Planned operational by end of decade. Not yet flown in space.

mass_kg.verification_notes: Not published. Checked Sierra Space official site and press releases.

volume_m3.verification_notes: Corrected from 300 to 285 m³ per official Sierra Space website. LIFE 1.0: 285 m³, LIFE 500: 500 m³, LIFE 1400: 1400 m³, LIFE 5000: 5000 m³. Stowed volume not disclosed.

dimensions.verification_notes: Corrected per official Sierra Space website. LIFE 1.0: 9m diameter x 6m length. Note: Some sources cite 27ft (8.2m) diameter, but official specs are 9m diameter.

crew_capacity.verification_notes: Corrected from 6 to 4. Primary design accommodates 4 astronauts comfortably. Can house 6 in LEO missions, up to 12 for short-term crew transitions. Three-story design with living quarters, labs, medical, exercise, and Astro Garden.

power_kw.verification_notes: Not published. Checked Sierra Space official site and press releases.

cost_usd.verification_notes: Not published. Checked Sierra Space official site and press releases.

procurement_lead_time.verification_notes: Not published. Planned operational by end of decade (before 2030).

design_life_years.verification_notes: Confirmed. Predicted life >60 years (525,600 hours) based on 15-year requirement with 4x safety factor per Sierra Space Chief Engineer.

pressure_specs.verification_notes: Corrected. Operating pressure 15.2 psi in LEO. Burst tests: 192 psi (Jul 2022 subscale), 204 psi (Nov 2022 subscale), 77 psi (Dec 2023 full-scale 285m³), 255 psi (Oct 2024 LIFE 10). Safety factor >16x in LEO, 23x in lunar environment (10.8 psi).

materials.verification_notes: Confirmed. Vectran™ fabric weave in high-strength softgoods layered structure, becomes stronger than steel when inflated per official Sierra Space website.

items.notes: Leading US inflatable habitat technology. Multiple variants planned. Designed for Orbital Reef commercial space station, potential lunar adaptation.

trl.verification_notes: Confirmed TRL 6. Ground testing complete including five burst tests (253-285 psi) and creep testing at NASA Marshall. In-space demo planned around 2030. Not yet space-flown.

mass_kg.verification_notes: Not published. Checked Lockheed Martin official site and Aviation Week coverage.

volume_m3.verification_notes: Confirmed 250 m³ coreless habitat design from Aviation Week. Airlock module ~9 m³. Compression ratios up to 5:1 axial, 2:1 radial. Stowed volume not specified.

dimensions.verification_notes: Airlock test article: 10.8 ft diameter barrel-shaped structure. Floor area not specified in authoritative sources.

crew_capacity.verification_notes: Airlock accommodates 2 astronauts in full spacesuits. Larger habitat crew capacity not disclosed.

power_kw.verification_notes: Not published. Checked Lockheed Martin official site.

cost_usd.verification_notes: Not published. Lockheed notes 'lower than traditional structures' but no figures given.

procurement_lead_time.verification_notes: Confirmed: Softgoods prototype completed in 8 weeks, built entirely in-house. Total system integration time unknown.

design_life_years.verification_notes: Confirmed 15 year minimum design life. Creep testing (4000+ hours at 4x design pressure) demonstrates potential for hundreds of years. NASA requires 4x safety factor equivalent to 60-year design life.

pressure_specs.verification_notes: Corrected with operating pressure. Max design pressure 15.2 psi. Burst tests: 285 psi (initial), 267 psi (Dec 2022 with penetration plate), 253 psi (Jun 2023), 224 psi (fifth test). Safety factor 14.7x achieved vs NASA 4x requirement.

materials.verification_notes: Confirmed Vectran fiber by Kuraray. Up to 8 protective layers for micrometeoroid and orbital debris defense. Custom webbing patterns.

items.notes: Purpose-designed for lunar surface with higher safety margins than orbital systems. In-space or surface demo expected around 2030. Part of NASA NextSTEP program.

trl.verification_notes: Corrected launch date from 2025 to 2026. TRL 6 estimated pre-flight. Prototype complete, awaiting SpaceX rideshare launch. Will reach TRL 7-8 post-demo.

mass_kg.verification_notes: Not published. Checked SpaceNews and TechCrunch coverage. Company emphasizes 'tiny fraction of mass' vs metallic structures but no specific mass disclosed.

volume_m3.verification_notes: Confirmed 2 m³ stowed (pancake configuration), 20 m³ deployed (10:1 expansion ratio). Largest expandable module to be flown to date per SpaceNews and TechCrunch.

crew_capacity.verification_notes: Not published. 2026 demo mission is proof-of-concept, likely uncrewed. Future crewed versions not specified.

cost_usd.verification_notes: Unit cost not disclosed. Company raised sub-$10M seed round funding development and rideshare launch. Future goal: ISS-equivalent volume for $200M including launch.

procurement_lead_time.verification_notes: Not published. Prototype described as 'stupidly simple to make' but delivery timeline not disclosed.

launch_details.verification_notes: Corrected from 2025 to 2026 per TechCrunch. LEO demonstration mission on SpaceX rideshare.

roadmap.description: 20 m³ (2026) → tens to hundreds m³ → thousands m³ for lunar/Mars missions
roadmap.verification_notes: Updated roadmap per TechCrunch. Phase 2: tens to hundreds m³ (comparable to current station modules). Long-term: thousands m³ for lunar caves and Mars.

technology.structure: 96 tendons rated to 17,000 lbs each, single-axis stress distribution
technology.verification_notes: Confirmed isotensoid architecture. Avoids bi-directional fabric 'basket weave' approach. 96 load-bearing tendons vs thousands of stitched intersections. Comparable strength to machined metal at fraction of mass.

heritage.founders: Aaron Kemmer (ex-Made In Space), Maxim de Jong (ex-Bigelow Aerospace, Genesis I/II designer, Thin Red Line Aerospace co-founder)
heritage.verification_notes: Confirmed founders and heritage. De Jong worked on ISS-attached inflatable and Genesis I/II. Kemmer led Made In Space programs.

items.notes: Largest expandable module to be flown to date (as of 2026 launch). Novel isotensoid architecture distinct from Bigelow/Sierra/Lockheed basket-weave designs. Designed for lunar cave interiors due to adaptable shape.

trl.verification_notes: Confirmed TRL 8. Integration and testing phase began April 2025. Pressurized module arrived from Thales April 1, 2025. Based on flight-proven Cygnus spacecraft (15+ ISS missions). Awaiting 2027 launch.

mass_kg.verification_notes: Confirmed 8-9 tons per GAO and space policy sources. Midpoint estimate 8500 kg. Combined PPE+HALO mass exceeds original target per GAO report.

volume_m3.verification_notes: Not published. Derived from Cygnus baseline with 1m extension, but specific pressurized volume not disclosed by NASA or Northrop Grumman.

dimensions.verification_notes: Confirmed 3m diameter (same as Cygnus), approximately 7m length (1m extension from Cygnus baseline) per Thales Alenia Space official source.

crew_capacity.verification_notes: Confirmed: Support up to 4 astronauts for up to 30 days when Orion spacecraft is docked, per Thales and NASA sources.

power_kw.verification_notes: Not published. HALO provides power distribution hub for PPE solar arrays and JAXA batteries, but internal power consumption not disclosed.

cost_usd.verification_notes: Corrected to $935M fabrication contract (firm fixed-price) per NASA official release July 2021. Northrop reported $36M loss on contract due to evolving requirements. Prior design contract was separate.

procurement_lead_time.verification_notes: Not disclosed. Timeline: Design contract 2020, fabrication contract July 2021, module arrival April 2025, launch December 2027.

docking_ports.verification_notes: Corrected to 3 total docking ports per Thales and NASA sources. Accommodates Orion, lunar landers, logistics vehicles, and future Gateway modules.

launch_details.verification_notes: Updated to December 2027 target per NASA commitment. Combined PPE+HALO launch. 9-10 month transit to lunar orbit. Supports Artemis IV mission September 2028.

heritage.verification_notes: Confirmed flight-proven Cygnus heritage per Thales and Northrop Grumman. Pressurized modules manufactured by Thales Alenia Space Italy.

contract_challenges.reason: Evolving Gateway architecture and macroeconomic challenges
contract_challenges.verification_notes: Confirmed $36M loss on fixed-price contract from changing requirements per SpaceNews.

items.notes: Rigid pressurized module, not inflatable. Gateway orbital element, NOT lunar surface. First foundational Gateway element. Mature Cygnus heritage technology.

trl.verification_notes: Confirmed TRL 5. Preliminary design phase contract signed July 2025 (2-year duration). Element Initiation Review completed Oct 2023. TRL 5-6 estimated based on early design phase.

mass_kg.verification_notes: Confirmed approximately 15 tonnes (15,000 kg) from Universe Magazine and European Spaceflight sources.

volume_m3.verification_notes: Not published. Checked Thales official sources and space industry coverage.

dimensions.verification_notes: Confirmed 6 meters length, 3 meters diameter from multiple credible sources.

crew_capacity.verification_notes: Confirmed: Designed for 2 astronauts, missions lasting 7-30 days, one mission per year from multiple sources.

power_kw.verification_notes: Not published. Checked Thales and ASI sources.

cost_usd.verification_notes: Not published. ASI contract value for preliminary design phase not publicly disclosed.

procurement_lead_time.verification_notes: Not published. Timeline: Preliminary design 2025-2027, launch 2033.

design_life_years.verification_notes: Confirmed minimum 10 years operational lifespan as permanent surface habitat per Thales official source.

mobility.verification_notes: Confirmed mobile capability. Recent design includes wheels. Can move and be precisely positioned on lunar surface.

launch_details.verification_notes: Confirmed 2033 launch from Kennedy Space Center per Thales official source.

environmental_challenges.verification_notes: Confirmed environmental protection features per Thales official source.

partnership.program: Artemis Accords bilateral cooperation with NASA

items.notes: First permanent pressurized habitat on lunar surface. Rigid structure, not inflatable. Mobile capability unique feature.

trl.verification_notes: Confirmed TRL 7. In development for Gateway. Mock-up complete 2024. Thales Alenia Space Italy prime contractor for ESA. Artemis IV will deliver I-Hab to Gateway.

mass_kg.verification_notes: Not published. Checked ESA and Thales official sources.

volume_m3.verification_notes: Confirmed approximately 10 m³ living space per ESA official source (volume of medium campervan). Combines with HALO for total Gateway habitat volume.

crew_capacity.verification_notes: Confirmed: Together with HALO, supports up to 4 astronauts for up to 90 days per ESA official source.

power_kw.verification_notes: Not published. I-Hab provides thermal control system but power consumption not disclosed.

cost_usd.verification_notes: Not published. ESA contract value not publicly disclosed.

procurement_lead_time.verification_notes: Not published. Artemis IV will deliver to Gateway (follows HALO/PPE launch).

docking_ports.configuration: 2 for Gateway connection, 2 for visiting vehicles
docking_ports.verification_notes: Confirmed: I-Hab serves as main entrance port to Gateway with 4 docking ports total per ESA.

partnership.jaxa_contribution: Environmental control, life support, batteries, thermal control
partnership.verification_notes: Confirmed ESA module with JAXA contributions per ESA official source.

launch_details.delivery_method: Orion spacecraft with European Service Module
launch_details.verification_notes: Confirmed: Artemis IV will bring I-Hab to Gateway, propelled by Orion/ESM. Follows HALO/PPE (Dec 2027) launch.

items.notes: Rigid pressurized module, not inflatable. Gateway orbital element, NOT lunar surface. ESA/JAXA contribution to Artemis program. Main entrance port and living quarters.

trl.verification_notes: Confirmed TRL 5. Ground testing at NASA Marshall with lunar regolith simulants and actual Apollo samples. Working toward TRL 6. $57.2M SBIR Phase III contract through 2028.

mass_kg.verification_notes: Not published. System mass not disclosed. Uses lunar regolith in-situ, eliminating habitat structure launch mass.

volume_m3.verification_notes: Not published. Scalable construction system, volume depends on mission requirements.

crew_capacity.verification_notes: Not applicable. Construction system builds infrastructure; habitat capacity depends on design requirements.

power_kw.verification_notes: Not published. High-powered laser system for regolith melting, but power requirements not disclosed.

cost_usd.verification_notes: Confirmed $57.2M NASA SBIR Phase III contract per NASA and ICON official sources (development funding through 2028, not per-unit cost).

procurement_lead_time.verification_notes: Not published. Construction time on lunar surface not disclosed.

contract_details.partner: NASA Marshall Space Flight Center (MMPACT project)
contract_details.verification_notes: Confirmed contract details per NASA official source.

technology.description: High-powered laser melts lunar regolith → solidifies into ceramic-like structures
technology.verification_notes: Confirmed technology approach per NASA official source.

applications.verification_notes: Confirmed applications per NASA official source.

testing.materials: Lunar regolith simulant and actual lunar samples
testing.verification_notes: Confirmed testing details per NASA official source.

earth_analog.name: Mars Dune Alpha
earth_analog.verification_notes: Confirmed: ICON 3D printed 1,700 sq ft Martian habitat at JSC demonstrating construction capabilities per NASA official source.

advantages.description: Better thermal, radiation, and micrometeorite protection than metal or inflatable habitats
advantages.verification_notes: Confirmed advantages per NASA official source.

items.notes: In-situ 3D printing using lunar regolith. Not a pre-fabricated habitat. Eliminates launch mass constraints for large structures.

items.application: Lunar surface (south pole, Shackleton crater area)

trl.notes: NASA ACO program participant. Vacuum chamber testing at -200°C completed. TRL 4-5 estimated.
trl.verification_notes: NASA ACO program participant. Vacuum chamber testing at -200°C completed. TRL 4-5 estimated.

mass_kg.notes: System mass not disclosed. 3D printing system uses regolith-polymer feedstock.
mass_kg.verification_notes: System mass not disclosed. 3D printing system uses regolith-polymer feedstock.

volume_m3.notes: Habitat volume scalable, depends on design
volume_m3.verification_notes: Habitat volume scalable, depends on design

crew_capacity.notes: Crew capacity not specified for LINA variant
crew_capacity.verification_notes: Crew capacity not specified for LINA variant

design_features.lighting: Skylight and intermittent windows creating light-well
design_features.notes: MARSHA (Mars) design adapted for lunar environment as LINA
design_features.verification_notes: MARSHA (Mars) design adapted for lunar environment as LINA

awards.notes: Won for MARSHA (Mars habitat), lunar variant LINA developed subsequently
awards.verification_notes: Won for MARSHA (Mars habitat), lunar variant LINA developed subsequently

items.notes: 3D printed in-situ construction. MARSHA design for Mars, LINA adaptation for Moon. Autonomous construction approach.

items.model: ECLSS (Environmental Control and Life Support System) for Lunar Habitats
items.application: Life support integration for lunar surface habitats

trl.notes: Heritage ISS systems TRL 9, new lunar variants TRL 7-8. 50+ years spaceflight experience.
trl.verification_notes: Heritage ISS systems TRL 9, new lunar variants TRL 7-8. 50+ years spaceflight experience.

mass_kg.notes: Modular pallets, specific mass not disclosed. NASA Surface Habitat design uses 10 pallets for ECLSS.
mass_kg.verification_notes: Modular pallets, specific mass not disclosed. NASA Surface Habitat design uses 10 pallets for ECLSS.

crew_capacity.notes: Scalable system, capacity depends on configuration. Supports up to 4 crew for lunar missions.
crew_capacity.verification_notes: Scalable system, capacity depends on configuration. Supports up to 4 crew for lunar missions.

system_capabilities.water: Water processing, urine and condensate processing

integration.habitat_config: 3 Collins Pallets in habitat core for Air Revitalization System

items.notes: Not a habitat structure itself, but critical life support integration. Modular palletized system for lunar Surface Habitat ECLSS.

items.application: Supplier/partner for inflatable habitats (lunar and orbital)

trl.notes: Partner to Sierra Space LIFE (TRL 6-7). Historical NASA projects varied TRLs.
trl.verification_notes: Partner to Sierra Space LIFE (TRL 6-7). Historical NASA projects varied TRLs.

mass_kg.notes: Component supplier, not complete system. Mass varies by project.
mass_kg.verification_notes: Component supplier, not complete system. Mass varies by project.

current_partnership.role: Exclusive softgoods partner for LIFE modules

products: Shelters for Earth orbit and lunar/planetary exploration

items.notes: Component supplier and partner, not prime habitat contractor. Critical technology provider for inflatable structures. Decades of NASA heritage.
